texts.shortText: Soft, delicate, worm-like organism with an unsegmented yellowish body divided into an acorn-like proboscis, a short collar section and an elongate trunk, the anterior part of which is wrapped by lateral lobes that cover a series of gill slits, behind which are a row of small khaki-coloured hepatic lobes.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to about East London.

Of evolutionary interest, as represents a link between the invertebrates and vertebrates, as has gill slits and a notocord (primitive backbone).

Constructs U-shaped burrows into sheltered sandbanks or in sediments between rocks and may reveal its presence by ejecting coiled sand-castings onto the sand surface. Moves sluggishly though sediments using ciliary action and muscular contractions of the proboscis.

Extremely delicate and frequently breaks up when excavated or handled, so probably more common that sampling results indicate.
Deposit feeder, consuming sediments and extracting organic matter from these.

Sexes are separate and the eggs and sperm released into the water via a small pore near the gill slits. The fertilized eggs develop into elongate planktonic larvae, which in most species develop directly into the adult form. In some species there is a second intermediate larval stage called a tornaria larva. This resembles the larvae of echinoderms, suggesting an evolutionary link between these groups.
Unlikely to be confused with other groups due to the unique body form. Replaced by the much larger (up to 1 m long!) B. natalensis along the east coast.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 244)

von Bonde, C (1934). The morphology of Balanoglossus capensis (Gilchrist), a species of Enteropneusta from False Bay. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 22(1), 17-33.
